PageElement.TextBox:
In this lesson you will learn about the Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines.

We will help you to apply your knowledge by asking you questions about a scenario. Please read the scenario carefully and keep it in mind as you work through the lesson.

Scenario questions are not scored and your response is not recorded. Use the feedback provided to consolidate what you have learned during this lesson.
 
Click on the Quick Facts menu button above to view a summary of the lesson.
 
Click the  ► button below to continue, or select a topic from the Table of Contents list.

PageElement.TextBox:
In this lesson you will learn about the Commonwealth Procurements Guidelines.
 
You should complete the lesson in about 20 minutes.
 
Y ou will learn:
 
  • What the Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines are;
  • Which organisations the Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines apply to;
  • The content of the Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines;
  • The types of procurement the Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines apply to; and
  • Time limits under the Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines.
 
To get started, please click on the ►button below.

Imagine that you work at the Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations.
 
The Department wants to acquire new office premises in Canberra to accommodate about 400 employees.
 
The Department decides it would be best to engage a contractor to purpose built premises on land the Commonwealth already owns. The estimated value of contract is $35 million.
 
You have been appointed as the project manager.
 
Consider this scenario while reading the next pages...

Page.Title: What are the Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines?

PageElement.TextBox:
There is a range of legislation and policies that Australian government agencies must comply with when procuring goods and services.
 
The most important of these is the Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines (CPGs) which are issued by the Finance Minister under Regulation 7 of the Financial Management and Accountability Regulations 1997 (Cth) (FMA Regulations.
 
Australian government organisations to which the CPGs apply must ensure they follow the CPGs when:
 
  • planning procurement of goods and services
  • drafting request for tender documentation
  • approaching the market with a tender
  • receiving and assessing tenders
  • selecting a preferred supplier
  • negotiating and signing a contract

PageElement.ExtraInfo:
• Click here for what does 'procurement' refer to?
    'Procurement' refers to the process of Australian government agencies entering contracts to buy goods and services.

    The common stages in a procurement process are:
     
    • an agency identifies a need for something, for example a contractor to clean the agencies' offices or a new server for the agencies' computer systems
     
    • the agency issues tender documentation describing what they need and inviting potential suppliers to submit a tender
     
    • suppliers submit tenders explaining how that supplier will deliver what is needed, how much it will cost and what terms and conditions should be in the contract
     
    • the agency evaluates the tender submissions received and decides which tender offers the best value for money
     
    • the agency negotiates with preferred supplier and signs a contract
    [Hide]

Page.Title: Who must comply with the CPGs?

PageElement.TextBox:
All bodies that are subject to the Financial Management and Accountability Act 1997 (FMA Act agencies) must comply with the CPGs. Click the box below for further details.

There are also some bodies that are subject to the Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Act 1997 (CAC Act bodies) that have been directed by the Finance Minister to comply with the CPGs.  However, they are only required to comply with the CPGs when undertaking 'covered procurements'. 
 
Click the second box below to find out what agencies are FMA Act agencies and what bodies are CAC Act bodies.

PageElement.ExtraInfo:
• Click here for FMA Regulation 7
    Regulation 7 of the Financial Management and Accountability Regulations states that:

    Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines (Act s 64)
     
    1. The Finance Minister may issue guidelines (to be called Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines) in relation to procurement, including:
     
      1. procurement policies and processes; and
     
      1. requirements regarding the publication of procurement details; and
     
      1. requirements regarding entering into procurement arrangements; and
     
      1. the disposal of public property.
     
    1. An official performing duties in relation to procurement must act in accordance with the Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines.
    [Hide]

• Click here for FMA Act agencies and CAC Act bodies
    FMA Act agencies are Australian government bodies subject to the Financial Management and Accountability Act 1997 (Cth) (FMA Act). Examples of FMA Act agencies are Departments of State, such as the Department of Finance and Deregulation and the Attorney-General's Department, and prescribed agencies, such as IP Australia and the Australian Taxation Office.
    A CAC Act body is an organisation subject to the Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Act 1997 (Cth) (CAC Act). CAC Act bodies are legally and financially independent from the Commonwealth. Examples of CAC Act bodies include the CSIRO and the National Gallery of Australia.
    The CAC Act allows the Finance Minister to direct some CAC Act bodies to comply with the CPGs when undertaking covered procurements. These bodies are listed in the Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Regulations (section 47A of the CAC Act).
    There are currently 18 Commonwealth Authorities and 1 company which are listed. There is a list of FMA Act agencies and CAC Act bodies that must comply with the CPGs on the Department of Finance and Deregulation's website.
    [Hide]

PageElement.TextBox:
The CPGs are divided into two divisions:
 
  • Division 1 – Procurement Principles
 
  • Division 2 – Mandatory Procurement Procedures

Division 1 contains general principles that apply to all procurements.

Division 2 contains specific procedures that agencies must apply in particular categories of procurement, which are called 'non-exempt covered procurements'.

Division 1 CPGs contains four Procurement Principles. The first one is value for money.
 
Value for money is the core principle underpinning the CPGs. Value for money requires a comparative analysis of all relevant costs and benefits of a proposal, including transition in and transition out costs.

Assessing value for money includes more than simply assessing the cost. The CPGs list six other criteria that should be included in a whole of life value for money assessment:
 
  • Fitness for purpose
 
  • Performance history of prospective suppliers
 
  • Relative risk of each tender
 
  • Flexibility to adapt to change over the lifecycle of the contract
 
  • Financial considerations including all direct and indirect costs and benefits over the lifecycle of the contract
 
  • Evaluation of contract options (eg options to extend)

The CPGs state that value for money is enhanced by following the other three Procurement Principles, encouraging competition, efficient, effective and ethical use of resources, and accountability and transparency.

The second procurement principle under Division 1 of the CPGs is encouraging competition.

Encouraging competition requires non–discrimination in procurement and the use of competitive procurement processes.

Non-discrimination is the principle that all suppliers should have the same opportunity to compete for Australian Government business based on their legal, technical and financial abilities and not on the basis of their origin.

The CPGs state that procurement methods should not discriminate against potential suppliers based on their degree of foreign affiliation, ownership, location or size.

Ensuring procurement methods do not prevent small to medium enterprises (SMEs) from participating is an important part of encouraging competition. For instance, agencies should not require a level of professional indemnity insurance too high for SMEs to obtain if that level of insurance is not necessary to cover the level of risk.

Following the procedures in Division 2 of the CPGs will assist agencies in selecting competitive procurement processes. Agencies can encourage competition by avoiding unnecessary requirements in specifications, avoiding inappropriate conditions for participation by vendors, advertising opportunities on AusTender, and specifying minimum periods for tender response.

The third procurement principle under Division 1 of the CPGs is efficient, effective and ethical use of resources.

This mirrors the requirement under section 44(3) of the FMA Act.

Efficient use of resources relates to the productivity of the resources used to conduct a procurement in order to achieve the maximum value for the resources used. This includes selecting a procurement process that is consistent with government policy and is the most appropriate to the procurement objective in the circumstances.

Effective use of resources relates to how well outcomes meet objectives. Agencies can ensure effective use of resources in procurement by accuracy in identifying the need and drafting the contract specifications, and assessing responses, managing and negotiating the contract with rigour.

Risk management, particularly management of limitations on the supplier's liability, is very important to ensuring efficient and effective use of resources.

Ethical use of resources includes acting with honesty, integrity, fairness, and consistency. Ethical issues that may arise in procurement include conflicts of interest and offers of gifts and hospitality from potential suppliers.

The final procurement principle under Division 1 of the CPGs is accountability and transparency.
 
Accountability means that government officials are responsible for their actions and decisions and the resulting outcomes in procurement, including being accountable for complying with government legislation and policy.
 
Transparency provides assurance that agencies are complying with government legislation and policy in procurement.
 
Maintaining documentation recording how a procurement was conducted is vital to accountability and transparency. Agencies need to ensure there is sufficient documentation to explain the reasons for the procurement, the process followed and the reasons and basis for all decisions.

There are some reporting requirements under the principles of accountability and transparency.  One of these is the requirement to report Commonwealth contracts or deeds of standing offer and amendments to these arrangements on AusTender within 6 weeks of entering into the arrangement.

PageElement.ExtraInfo:
• Click here for AusTender
    AusTender is a website where Australian government agencies publish government business opportunities, annual procurement plans, multi-use lists and contracts awarded.

    AusTender includes facilities for Australian government agencies to release tender documentation for response and receive tender responses electronically.

    Further information can be accessed on the AusTender website
    [Hide]

PageElement.TextBox:
For FMA agencies the reporting requirements apply to all contracts over $10,000. 

For CAC Act bodies the threshold is $9 million for procurement of construction services and $400,000 for other procurements.
 
Agencies need to balance the need to keep their own and suppliers' information confidential against their reporting and disclosure obligations when conducting procurement.  The Guidance on Confidentiality in Procurement sets out further details regarding confidentiality obligations to suppliers:
 
The next section covers the Mandatory Procurement Procedures

Division 2 of the CPGs (Mandatory Procurement Procedures) outlines procedures that agencies must comply with when procuring goods or services where the value of the tender is over a certain threshold and not covered by an exemption.

The Mandatory Procurement Procedures cover:
 
  • choice of procurement method
 
  • drafting tender documentation
 
  • conditions for participation in tenders
 
  • minimum time limits
 
  • receiving and opening submissions
 
  • when agencies may award contracts
 
  • how to notify successful and unsuccessful suppliers about the decision

Agencies conducting procurement need to determine whether the Mandatory Procurement Procedures in Division 2 of the CPGs apply by following two steps.

Step 1

First, agencies must determine whether the procurement is a covered procurement. Division 2 (Mandatory Procurement Procedures) of the CPGs defines covered procurements in paragraph 8.4.

A covered procurement is a procurement with an estimated value over a certain threshold:
 
  • for construction services the threshold is $9 million
  • for FMA Act agencies, the threshold for procurements, other than construction services, is $80,000
  • for CAC Act bodies, the threshold for procurements, other than construction services, is $400,000

PageElement.ExtraInfo:
• Click here for estimated value covered procurements
    When valuing a procurement agencies are required to take into account any options to extend in the contract and all forms of costs including 'any premiums, fees, commissions, interest and other revenue streams' as well as 'any taxes or charges' including GST under paragraph 8.6 of the CPGs.

    Attempting to avoid a procurement threshold by dividing the procurement into separate parts is inconsistent with the Mandatory Procurement Procedures. If the valuation of the procurement is close to the threshold or there is a possibility it may exceed the threshold, the Agency should consider the procurement covered (see the Procurement Policy Framework FAQs Question 34 on the Department of Finance and Deregulation website).

    If agencies are not sure whether or not a procurement will be valued over the thresholds they should treat it as a covered procurement.
    [Hide]

PageElement.TextBox:
Step 2

Agencies must comply with the Mandatory Procurement Procedures when undertaking a covered procurement unless it is exempt.

Appendix A of the CPGs specifies 15 categories of exempted procurements.

If an FMA Act agency conducts an exempt procurement it must still comply with the procurement policy framework and other government policies specified in the CPGs.

If a CAC Act agency conducts an exempt procurement it is not required to comply with any parts of the CPGs.

PageElement.ExtraInfo:
• Click here for exempted procurements
    Examples of exempted procurements include:
     
    • leasing or purchasing of real property or accommodation
     
    • the procurement of government advertising services
     
    • the procurement of motor vehicles.
    [Hide]

PageElement.TextBox:
If the Mandatory Procurement Procedures apply then one of the things agencies must consider in planning the procurement and issuing tender documentation is the minimum time limits for organisations to lodge tenders.

The Mandatory Procurement Procedures state that there must be a common tender closing time for all organisations.

Agencies issuing an open tender or a select tender must allow a minimum of 25 calendar days from the date and time the agency publishes the tender for the tender lodgement deadline.

In certain circumstances the CPGs allow agencies to establish a time limit for lodgement of submissions that is less than 25 calendar days.  The circumstances are listed in paragraph 8.58 and include:
 
  • where the agency has already published details of the procurement in their Annual Procurement Plan between 30 days and 12 months earlier
 
  • where there is a genuine state of urgency

In all cases the  time limit must be at least 10 calendar days, must be reasonable and allow sufficient time for potential suppliers to prepare and lodge submissions.

If the approach to the market is not advertised or published on AusTender, the minimum timeframe is extended to 30 days.  This gives agencies an added incentive to comply with the requirement (in the CPGs) to publish invitations on AusTender.

The key questions to ask yourself to determine whether the CPGs and the Mandatory Procurement Procedures apply to your procurement.
 
  1. What kind of agency is procuring the goods and services? Is it an FMA Act Agency or CAC Act body?
 
  1. What type of goods or services are you procuring?
 
  1. Which threshold applies ($80,000, $400,000 or $9 million)?
 
  1. If the estimated value of your procurement is over the relevant threshold, is it exempt?

The Procurement Policy Framework FAQs on the Department of Finance and Deregulation website are a useful resource in applying the CPGs
Do you remember the scenario?

PageElement.ExtraInfo:
• If not, click here for a reminder and then try answering the question below.
    Imagine that you work at the Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations.

    The Department wants to acquire new office premises in Canberra to accommodate about 400 employees.

    The Department decides it would be best to engage a contractor to build purpose built premises on land the Commonwealth already owns. The estimated value of contract is $35 million.

    You have been appointed as the project manager.
    [Hide]

PageElement.MultiChoiceQA:
Do the CPGs apply to your agency?
 
(a) Yes
That is correct.

The Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations is subject to the FMA Act. All Departmental officials are required to Regulation 7 of the Financial Management and Accountability Regulations to comply with the CPGs.
(b) No
Sorry, that is incorrect.

The correct answer is 'yes' because the Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations is subject to the FMA Act. All Departmental officials are required to Regulation 7 of the Financial Management and Accountability Regulations to comply with the CPGs.

PageElement.TextBox: Do you remember the scenario?

PageElement.ExtraInfo:
• If not, click here for a reminder and then try answering the question below.
    Imagine that you work at the Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations.

    The Department wants to acquire new office premises in Canberra to accommodate about 400 employees.

    The Department decides it would be best to engage a contractor to build purpose built premises on land the Commonwealth already owns. The estimated value of contract is $35 million.

    You have been appointed as the project manager.
    [Hide]

PageElement.MultiChoiceQA:
Do you need to comply with the Mandatory Procurement Procedures?
 
(a) Yes, the procurement is a covered procurement.
That is correct.

The value of the procurement is over the relevant threshold of $9 million dollars for construction services in paragraph 8.4 of the CPGs and it is not within one of the categories of exempt procurement in Appendix A of the CPGs.
(b) No, the procurement is below the relevant threshold.
Sorry, that is incorrect.

The building of a new building is construction services and the relevant threshold is $9 million under paragraph 8.4 of the CPGs. The project's estimated value is $35 million and is over the relevant threshold. Therefore, the procurement is covered and you must comply with the Mandatory Procurement Procedures. The correct answer is 'yes.'
(c) No, the procurement is above the relevant threshold but it is exempt.
Sorry, that is incorrect.

The procurement is over the relevant threshold but it is not exempt. The exemptions in Appendix A of the CPGs for purchasing real property or accommodation apply to land or to existing buildings. Your agency is obtaining the services of an organisation to build a new building. This means that the procurement is not exempt. Since the procurement is above the relevant threshold of $9 million for construction services you must comply with the Mandatory Procurement Procedures. The correct answer is 'yes.'

PageElement.TextBox: Do you remember the scenario?

PageElement.ExtraInfo:
• If not, click here for a reminder and then try answering the question below.
    Imagine that you work at the Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations.

    The Department wants to acquire new office premises in Canberra to accommodate about 400 employees.

    The Department decides it would be best to engage a contractor to build purpose built premises on land the Commonwealth already owns. The estimated value of contract is $35 million.

    You have been appointed as the project manager.
    [Hide]

PageElement.MultiChoiceQA:
The Secretary is anxious for a contractor to be engaged so that Departmental staff working on similar tasks can be co-located.  Can you shorten the tender opening period to 14 days?
 
(a) No
That is correct.

The Mandatory Procurement Procedures provide that the minimum time limit for tender submissions is 25 days after the tender is released for responses. The fact that the Secretary is anxious for a contractor to be engaged so that Departmental staff can be co-located is not a 'genuine state of urgency' under the Mandatory Procurement Procedures.
 
(b) Yes so long as the tender documents are made available for download on AusTender or otherwise issued electronically.
Sorry, that is incorrect.

The Mandatory Procurement Procedures provide that the minimum time limit for tender submissions is 25 calendar days after the tender is released for responses. The minimum period would be even longer if the tender was not advertised electronically.
 
The correct answer is 'no'.
(c) Yes, because the Secretary has decided that the project is a priority and it will enhance the Department's ability to undertake its functions.
Sorry, that is incorrect.

The Mandatory Procurement Procedures provide that the minimum time limit for tender submissions is 25 calendar days after the tender is released for responses. The fact that the Secretary is anxious for a contractor to be engaged is not a 'genuine state of urgency' under the Mandatory Procurement Procedures. The correct answer is 'no'.

PageElement.TextBox:
Congratulations! You have completed your lesson.
 
Click the End Lesson button to exit the lesson.
